French laws dont forbid layoffs, but the company will have to pay a mandatory layoff package for each employee based on years of employment, and the company will be forbidden to rehire the laid off position for a long period, 3 years i think, except if rehiring the same person that was laid off.

I wont defend Ubisoft in general, but delaying the game because it needs more time, and ommitting a season pass from this type of game are both the right decisions in my opinion. Seasonal content makes sense for some games, but theyve been getting shoehorned into everything lately as a revenue source, to the detriment of the games. And it feels like almost every other big game release lately has been plagued with issues that get sorted out eventually, but they probably would have been better off delaying and launching a more polished product in the first place. For these reasons alone, I hope AC Shadows is good and does well. Hopefully the gaming industry will take note and will start moving back towards quality over cashgrabs.

The games industry as a whole somewhat relies on passionate, fresh juniors coming into the industry and being exposed daily to more senior staff of whom they can learn from. These juniors will often do a lot of the grunt work and a whole deal of fixes and improvements throughout each project. Without that direct contact with more experienced staff, the speed of development and overall output in these large studios is vastly reduced. This, coupled with the covidera graduates which have also had an inferior collegeuni education, means the next generation of developers is less prepared for work than ever. The knock on effect of this is underbaked, underfeatured games that get delayed and have a whole slew of issues on release. Unless motivation and production is absolutely on point, this will continue until studios adapt properly to distributed development.

Whats the alternative? It takes that much time to make thousands and thousands of models to fill these massive expansive worlds that people want to run around in. To some extent you can solve it by just hiring more people, but that makes communication more difficult and just keeps ballooning the costs. And some parts of game dev dont really benefit from more hands in the cookie jar. Tweaking a physics system for example. Theres only so many knobs you can turn at once before you just have to test and tune some more. If theres only 100 variable values that control the physics system, hiring 300 devs and 500 testers to get it right isnt going to do you much good. The same will hold true for dozens and dozens of other game systems where there is an optimal number of devs and testers, and adding any more is just diminishing returns.

IMO that shows exactly why the modern video game industry is so broken. Spending 5 to 6 years on a single game is just absurd. people are fighting it kicking and screaming, but ai is going to be a MASSIVE improvement for the gaming industry. its going to reduce timelines so much by eliminating lots of grunt work plus the computers will be able to work 247. well get bigger games faster. one of the big debates in rpgs for example is if its better to have a voiced main character or an unvoiced main character because an unvoiced one can give so many more dialog options due to the timemoney involved in recording all the audio paths if its voiced. and while a company like EA can put up that money for something like mass effect, it still takes time, and a smaller company like atlus cant do that for persona.

Okay, while Im not a fan of Ass Creed since the french revolution one and FC3 is the last I played from that series, still making AAA games is expensive and takes many, many people involved. Even if they use the same engine and many of the same assets, they still need to put it all together, create new animations for cutscenes, pay voice actors, directors, writers, composers etc. Even is code for lets say the sword is the same, they still need an artist to make viking sword in to a katana etc. Those games are huge, there are a lot of things to do and many people need to to that. Just because the management and money people dont love games and have 0 passion, does not mean we should put down the huge work hundreads of people do there.

Youre trivialising the entirety of project management Time, cost and quality are interrelated. You always have to balance quality vs the other metrics. So no, quality is not a set standard Examples A minor UI improvement might be nice, but is it worth setting us back 2 months? Or, we have a 5 chance of a gamebreaking bug, but itll take an extra 9 months and 5 mn to fully test everything. Is 95 safe good enough to ship the game and fix reactively if a bug surfaces? Decisions like that are made every sprint during development and testing This is like the first thing you learn about project management. Obviously its ideal to hit all your time cost quality targets, but if you cant get all three you have to decide what to sacrifice
Tell that to the people playing Elden Ring. The discovery of that hidden cave, that secret lore tidbit in the obscure area....they live for that stuff.

Harmful even because it will give you answers that look fine, but perform like absolute garbage. You need engineers and human touch to make art, and thats not gonna change because of AI any time soon.

Anyone who thinks AI is ready to take jobs in the software development field has no concept of how software development works. . It can help you lay out HTML and CSS for a website, sure. Its REALLY good at that. As soon as you have complex questions about how a data layer should be optimized or something in a highly custom application....its useless. you realize there is a lot moe to game development than coding, correct? ai can end the voiced vs unvoiced main character debate because it will no longer be unfeasible to voice all the various branching dialog paths 99 of which wont be heard on a given playthrough.

But to answer your sacrifice. Just dont start at all if you cant deliver quality... then the game just isnt it. A games developer that doesnt develop games because they assume theyll fail... A bold move, cotton, lets see how it plays out for them Youre quite naive to how things work. Hypothetical example Lets say quality is a set standard. You have a goal to hit a quality level acceptable in 2024. But you encounter so many delays that, to do this, you can only release in 2030 Do you stick to the original scope and release something 6 years out of date by the time its ready? Your customers hate it anyway assuming you avoided bankruptcy from no revenue for years Or do you cut some things out so you can at least get something out earlier, with a hit to reputation but at least you survive? Your customers might dislike it but less than the first option Obviously, best case scenario is always deliver projects on time, to quality and under budget. But youre very, very laughably naive if you think that happens all the time Time cost quality sacrifices are made all the time it doesnt mean companies hate their customers. It means they overpromised and underdelivered

You might want to check out the strike going on right now related to AI use in video games. Its specifically about voice actors and MoCap actors atm. They are not ready to be replaced by AI so quickly

AI cannot replicate the parts of human experience that make art art. EVERYBODY hates the stupid TikTok AI voice. You can pick it out of a lineup of voices 10001000 times. Its obnoxious. It has no emotion. It doesnt understand how to pause for drama, how to use inflection properly to emphasize things. The same is true for visual art. If you ask AI to draw you 100 character sprites, youre going to get like 70 different art styles that dont look cohesive together. Sure....you can try to reign it in with parameters. You can give it a color palette. You can train it on a data set that is all of a similar style that it will try to replicate. But youve removed the human element and made everything cold and samey. REAL artists know when they can break the rules like using something outside of the standard palette for artistic effect. When you remove the artist, you remove all the complexity that makes people feel something when they look at it. The same is true for code. You can go to school and learn best practices all you want. But there are times in code when it absolutely makes sense to do things that are antipattern. Things that go against the grain of common sense. But an AI trained on nothing but textbooks that say DO NOT EVER DO THIS is never going to reach that unique solution. People who are not software engineers are not qualified to tell me a degree holding engineer when or if AI is going to take my job. You have absolutely NO concept of what it cancant do in terms of code, you dont have the skills to analyze it appropriately. You can tell it to write you a bunch of code, and it will spit out a bunch of complex looking stuff. And you, as a noncoder, will look at it and be like wow thats wild. But you dont know if it gave you anything useful because you arent qualified in this field to judge it. Just like I can give ChatGPT a list of medical symptoms and it will spit out a bunch of medical jargon that looks really smart. But I am not a doctor. I am absolutely not qualified to determine whether or not ChatGPT made up a bunch of shit that isnt true. I dont have the skills or knowledge to make that determination. The type of people who think AI is going to take over have a very tenuous grasp of how it even works. It shouldnt even be called intelligence because it isnt doing ANYTHING smart. It works EXACTLY the same way as the predictive text on your phone keyboard. It takes its best guess as to what the next word in the sentence is. Nothing more. Nothing less. It isnt capable of reasoning and we arent anywhere near making a breakthrough to change that. AI also isnt capable of understanding the nuances that make people feel emotional over artistic content. And it never will. At best it is a tool to let existing engineers speed up certain parts of their workflow. Im not losing my job to AI. Not in one decade, or two. Probably not in my lifetime.
Youll wouldve been the ones defending tobacco companies in the 90s
If I cant deliver as intented and the customer wont like it. Just cut it and move on. This will hurt your reputation far more than it restoring whatever... Have some gut and admit the loss...

They are not ready to be replaced by AI so quickly just because they dont want to be replaced doesnt mean that the technology isnt ready to replace a lot of what they do and will be able to fully replace them in a few years. at the end of the day, they just cant offer the same performance, price, availability as ai. if companies can shave a year or two off of their dev times, they owe it to their shareholders and their customers to do so.

AI cannot replicate the parts of human experience that make art art. you can believe that, but at the end of the day youll quickly find out that such a claim isnt true. And you, as a noncoder, bold assumption there.

What does cut and move on mean? You sound like a kid whos never worked a day in their life On multimillion dollar projects, you dont simply say oh well, better luck next time. You get fired if you cant salvage something
removed

Cut means, leave it for what it was... But you assuming I never worked a day in my life is hilarious... But Id love to see how you explain this shit to stakeholders lol... they absolutely gonna love you for coming in with well better to salvage whatever is left when stocks are plummeting... Id say you can look for another company than throwing around millions like that....
Invite me into your shareholders meeting when you present them such bs lol.

Cut means, leave it for what it was... Which is cutting on quality. The very thing you said was a red line companies would be stupid to cross Youre all over the place. You clearly have no experience in how these projects work only in playing games Maybe stick to topics you actually know about, eh?
removed

Ah... Because giving up and effectively firing yourself has no repercussions and certainly doesnt impact your future trajectory You really have no idea how corporate life works What if you cant jump ship, simply because youre not the brightest tool in the shed? I suspect you might have some personal experience with that sooner or later

ok. so.. DVI. VGA. and SVideo ? Hmm. 4 banks. and that AGP tail. So. 32mb GeForce ?? the 256 model. thats my guess. Looks like something that came with Gateway2000 computers.
Researcher We need a photo of a Advanced Nvidia GPU Dude pulls first one from a google search after Nvidia celebrated its anniversary...

at least there indeed is a GPU on the picture they find. btw, this is a GeForce 256, the first GPU in the world. It is the first piece of hardware which can take vector data about shapes and light settings and output rendered video on its own.
Tony Stark was able to build this in a cave!
deleted
That is a picture I havent seen in a while
I remember this one.
What is this? Is this about the dude who bought a bunch of high end AI chips and outsourced AI acceleration to China? As far as i know its American and UAE money and the farm was in Australia....
They dont make them like they used to. The GPU landscape is so much better in the old days
Slow news day.
Its like an original TnT card.
China will distribute the banned goods to less than ideal players who are banned. So its going to be largely performative unless theres more controls.
Bullish for democracy.
Recently publicised photo as nvidias first, which it wasnt but, whatever... News aint close to accurate anymore on any topic, why do we assume they would be here.
I have like 20 cards from that era that I have recycled. I can finally flip them.
Cave was able to Tony this in a Stark build.
Plus if it was decent itd be full length.
I think the GeForce 256 was the first GPU. Didnt Jensen coin that name when they included transform and lighting functions on the chip for the first time?
Well Tony not Im Stark.
Nah, the riva 128 was the first proper one, nv1 had limited success.
I think in the riva128 voodoo days they were just called graphics cards or 3d accelerators. The GPU name happened when they included more processing features. Not that it matters at all.
I member saving money for a year to buy my voodoo 3 2000? 3000? Shit was out of this world fast!

Dude, no, shut up. My tseng labs 4000 was called a gpu, the gpu being the chip on the graphics card. Theres a history of this on Wikipedia. Probably need to review it, considering the terminology dates back to sgi in the 80s, possibly further.
If you still have it, they are a collectible now. Ebay prices for voodoo cards are 100 now lol.
I have 2 SGI machines in my office. Silicon Graphics was absolutely not calling the collection of DSP chips in their graphics sub system a GPU.
This you?
Its like looking in a mirror.
I mean, yall are arguing over ancient chipsets. Is this one of those circumstances where the community should come together and get yall a prostitute so you can finally become men?

Ever since they made that acquisition back in April 2023, the company has been in a freewill which doesn't say much about management and the future of the company. Acquisitions are made to enhance shareholder value not destroy it.
